title: Jobs lost in Tui Brewery upgrade
text:
Jobs lost in Tui Brewery upgrade 
Friday 14 Aug 2015 1:18 p.m. 
DB Brewery has confirmed two dozen jobs will be cut at its Tui Brewery in Mangatainoka as it downscales brewing operations there. 
DB says up to $5 million will be spent on upgrading the Tararua brewery and earthquake-strengthening the site's 84-year-old seven-storey brick tower as it becomes more "fit for purpose". 
It currently employs 37 people but the new set up will mean the loss of 13 full-time and 11 part-time jobs, the company confirmed today. 
The change will "safeguard the future" of brewing onsite, but changes to production requirements will mean brewery will have a smaller capacity, it says. 
Spokesman Matt Wilson says the changes will not take effect until the new brewery is operational, expected to be in May next year. 
"This has not been an easy decision to come to and itâ€™s certainly not something anyone at DB has taken lightly. We've considered a spectrum of options and we believe that the best outcome for the region and the brand is to keep an operational brewery on site at reduced production capacity," he says. 
It is hoped some of the affected staff can relocate to other DB sites or be redeployed to the new brewery. Some will help with help decommission the existing brew plant. 
DB says six bespoke Tui beers will be brewed and served at the new plant and it will give it more flexibility to experiment with new beers. 
The 126-year-old site, with a restaurant and museum, hosts functions, weddings, events and tours. 
About 45,000 people visit every year and the changes will help it cope with an expected 30 percent increase in visitor numbers. 
The work shows DB is committed to staying in Mangatainoka, Tui marketing manager Nick Rogers says. 
DB, owned by Heineken, also has breweries in Auckland, Timaru and Greymouth. 
The Tui Tower is a Category 1 Heritage listed building and as part of the work will undergo base isolation work, with Fletcher Building to replace the foundations with sliding bearings designed to absorb and cushion the movement of earthquakes. 
3 News / NZN
